content.title: Above-Knee Amputation (Transfemoral Amputation)
content.description: Major lower extremity amputation through the femur, performed when below-knee amputation is not feasible due to inadequate healing potential or extensive tissue loss.
content.definition: Above-knee amputation (AKA) or transfemoral amputation removes the leg above the knee joint. While providing reliable healing, loss of the knee significantly impairs prosthetic ambulation and increases energy expenditure. Reserved for patients who cannot heal a more distal amputation.

surgical_technique: Fish-mouth incision with equal anterior/posterior flaps
Or anterior longer than posterior for sitting comfort
Preserve maximum femoral length for leverage
Myodesis of adductors to femur prevents abduction contracture
Sciatic nerve division high to prevent neuroma in prosthetic socket
indications: Failed BKA or poor BKA healing potential
healing_rates: Rarely requires revision to hip disarticulation

learning_objectives: Identify indications for AKA over BKA
Understand functional limitations compared to BKA
Recognize importance of femoral length preservation
clinical_pearls: Every effort should be made to preserve the knee before proceeding to AKA
Non-ambulatory status is not an absolute indication for AKA over BKA
Longer residual limb provides better prosthetic leverage
Early mobilization important to prevent hip flexion contracture
